thread.title_full: Government bank should be set targets to help lending to regions like the North East, report says

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Government bank should be set targets to help lending to regions like the North East, report says
text:
Government bank should be set targets to help lending to regions like the North East, report says 14:35, 31 Oct 2016 14:35, 31 Oct 2016 By Graeme Whitfield Business Select Committee highlights fears that leaving Europe will harm the funding landscape for UK businesses Share Get business news by email Digital Vision 
The British Business Bank should be measured by the amount it lends to companies in regions like the North East to help meet the gap in funding for firms wanting to grow, a key Parliamentary committee has said . 
The Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy (BEIS) Select Committee says lending to ambitious companies has improved since the financial crash, but concerns are growing that the vote to leave the European Union could set the funding landscape back significantly. 
The committee has also highlighted concerns that attracting funding can be harder outside London and the South East where many of the big institutional lenders are based. 
MPs have welcomed the establishment of a Northern Powerhouse fund at the British Business Bank, the Government-owned lender that aims to help small businesses as they look to scale-up and grow. 
But the committee - which is chaired by North East MP Iain Wright - says that the bank should be given a new performance measurement to “assess its effectiveness in incentivising lending and investment activity in all parts of the UK”. 
The committee’s report says: “The new Prime Minister has already spoken of her desire for opportunity and economic success to be more fairly distributed across the UK, and we look forward to learning how the Government intends to use the various levers at its disposal to make this happen. 
“Enabling entrepreneurs to start their own business, and ensure they can access finance as they grow, can have an important role in rebalancing economic growth across the UK. 
“The willingness of the Government to intervene where there are identifiable market failures in the business landscape across the whole UK represents a test and an opportunity in the context of its new industrial strategy.” Coventry Telegraph Archive Dr Adam Marshall 
The committee highlights fears that the June 23 vote to leave the EU will have repercussions for access to finance and warns too that the European Investment Bank has provided large amounts of money to underpin finance for business that could be lost when the Brexit process is complete. 
The Start-Up Loans company - which recently announced it had provided £10m to help North East companies - is singled out as a “good and effective way” to support new entrepreneurs. 
Responding to the report, Dr Adam Marshall, director general of the British Chambers of Commerce, said: “Access to finance remains an issue for many growing businesses, and the problem is often greater the further a firm is from the angels and venture capital firms concentrated inside the M25. 
“We welcome the committee’s support for an even-stronger regional dimension to the Government’s business finance initiatives. The work of the British Business Bank and others to create investment funds focused on the Northern Powerhouse, the Midlands Engine and other areas away from the capital can and should be intensified.” 
Tim Sawyer, CEO at the Start Up Loans Company, said: “Small businesses are often referred to as the lifeblood of the economy, and start-ups play an instrumental role in this. That’s why it’s great to see such a demand for funding from potential business owners up and down the country. 
“Achieving £10m of lending in the North East is a key milestone for the Start Up Loans Company and we are keen to help many more business ideas come to fruition. 
“Since 2012, our funding and comprehensive package of free business support has helped to create jobs and launch many great business ideas. As a result, the scheme has delivered more than £3 of value to the economy for every £1 invested.”
